oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States. Army -- Military Police; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Prisoners and prisons; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Psychological aspects; Courts -- martial and courts of inquiry

Report of Prisoners in custody of Provost Guard Columbia June 16 / 62 Joseph Ingraham. Citizen Captured By Capt. Davis 7th Penna. Cavelry. At the time of advance on Rodgersville. (No Charges) J. D. Wortham – Citizen – Sent By Capt. Lowrie (No Charges (About May 18th) John Redman ) F. Conrad ) Patrick Lancry ) Co. K. 35th Regt. Ind. Vol. Michael Lancry) Charges Preferred Capt. Lowrie A.A.G and handed to Lieut. Nevin (Judge Advocate have been confined one month. John Henderson – Comp. B. 35 Reg. Ind. Vol. Hospital nurse. Drunk & Disorderly In confinement three days. J. B. Linsley – Comp. – 5th Ky Cavelry J. M. Strode – Comp. – K “ & & Released to W. B. Branham “ - - & & Col Hazzard (No Charges) and to be returned if poof is found against them. John Sevir – Comp. I. 79th Regt. P.A. Insubordination. Refusal to do duty Physically and mentally deranged. Charles Carter. Comp. 35th Ind. Vol No Charges In confinement one month Confirmed by Col Walker
[Page 2 of 2]
Daniel Early – Comp I. 7th Penn Cavelry John R. Rimple & & ----- Arrested by order from Head Quarters No Charges Released to Sergt. Hopkins – and to be returned if proof is found against them. By his order
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Double-sided, handwritten, one-page document lists those prisoners being held by Federal authorities. Those incarcerated include citizens, soldiers who have committed disciplinary infractions, and soldiers being held for possible court-martial.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: United States -- Provost Marshal's Office
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Record Group 21, Adjutant General's Office Records, 1796-1900
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Note the soldier denoted as "Physically and Mentally deranged." Though two-thousand cases of insanity and five-hundred suicides were recorded among the 600,000 soliders who served in the Federal Army, the limitations of nineteenth century notions of war, medicine, and mental illness- and the infancy of psychiatry and neurology- suggest we lack the full picture of combat stress. Research shows younger Civil War soldiers who saw more comrades die or who were POWs had increased physical and mental ailments later in life.
